report_title: Golf Courses & Country Clubs in the US Industry Report
executive_summary: As social distancing regulations continued, golf remained an activity that could be done while adhering to regulations. Once stay-at-home orders were lifted, attendance at courses and country clubs shot up and revenue grew significantly.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Golf has not captured the attention of young athletes
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The stagnating popularity of golf has significantly hampered industry expansion during the period. Without enough demand to sustain them, many courses and clubs have been forced to close. Golf courses are extraordinarily popular among retirees, but golf hasn't grown much in terms of popularity among younger consumers. Baseball, football, soccer, hockey and basketball are all far more engaging sports for young athletes. Individual sports programs, like tennis, cross country and track and field, are also accessible at most public schools, while golf is less common as a school sport.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Golf participation rates have been falling over most of the past decade. Some individuals find the etiquette, rules and dress codes off-putting, while others find that the game takes too long to play. But country club memberships are expected to rise over the coming years as high corporate profit and disposable income bolster demand from both businesses and individual consumers. Golf participation grows with increased leisure time, particularly among retired individuals who don't engage in more intense recreational activities. Consumer leisure time is expected to grow over the next five years, though at a restrained pace. This may generate more interest in the sport, especially as many customers of the industry are older and retired.

industry_definition: This industry is primarily engaged in operating golf courses and country clubs that have dining and recreational facilities. These businesses typically provide food and beverage services, equipment rental services and golf instruction. Golf courses can be public, private, semiprivate or an extension of a private country club. This industry excludes golf driving ranges, miniature golf courses and resorts and hotels that have on-site golf courses.

key_trends: Participation in the game of golf has declined in recent years. This has had a negative impact on the industry.
There are currently more golf courses in the United States than there are players to occupy them. This stands to hold back the industry.

Upcoming growth in demand is suggested by multiple external drivers. The growth in disposable income, rise in consumer confidence and the increasing number of households earning more than $100,000 is expected over the coming years.
Companies that operate golf courses must abide by strict environmental regulations. Golf course operators are responsible for a significant amount of land.
Memberships and green fees are just one source of revenue. Courses and country clubs make a lot from other ventures, like food and beverage sales and equipment rental.
The older population is not participating in the game as much as they have historically. This is perhaps due to the average age of retirement being pushed to later in life.
A successful course should be established in an area with land available for a good price. A temperate climate allows playing year-round.
Golf courses in colder climates have higher costs for green maintenance. Dry or cold winter seasons can damage grounds.
There is competition between many small companies and a few large operators over the same populations. The existence of small companies prevents large ones from growing their operations.
Golf players have an abundance of choice when it comes to where they will play. It ultimately comes down to the quality of services and cost of playing at a club or course.
Major players in this industry have labor forces varying drastically in size. Some players employ between 10,000 and 30,000 employees, while others employ far less, between 60 and 200.
Most major players are currently growing. This includes their market share, profit margin and revenue.
Larger companies benefit from economies of scale, reducing their costs significantly compared to smaller operators.
Country clubs and golf courses have high wage costs. These can be reduced by automating some services, like check-in and equipment rental.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Country club memberships typically entitle a member to either unlimited golf games throughout the year or a set amount, often in addition to access to the associated country club facilities and events. Membership fees have increased as rates have steadily improved alongside the economy.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Revenue from Green Fees has Risen Thanks to Increasing Accessibility
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Green fees are fees paid by golfers who are not members of a country club but wish to play an individual round of golf. According to data from the National Golf Foundation, golf is relatively accessible with 75.0% of facilities being open to the public.

The bulk of this segment is generated through sales of alcoholic beverages, although revenue is also generated through nonalcoholic beverages, meals and catered events. This segment remains highly profitable as disposable income has expanded and consumers have become more willing to splurge on eating and drinking on the course.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Equipment Rentals and Sales are Reliable Streams of Revenue
demand_determinants.determinant_description: The rental and sale of golf carts, clubs and other equipment make up a small but crucial segment of revenue. Nearly all courses offer equipment rental for customers who don't have their own.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Other Revenue-Earning Operations Include Hosted Corporate and Party Event Services
demand_determinants.determinant_description: This segment also includes miscellaneous services such as room rental or unit accommodation for club players, registration for sports tournaments and matches and other paid club activities.

business_locations.location_description: The high number of establishments in the region benefit from the continually warm climate and the relatively few days that could be potentially ruined by bad weather. Florida holds 6.3% of the industry's establishments, more than any other state.

The high number in the region is a result of lower land prices and high-water levels conducive to lower maintenance and operating costs, improving profitability. Several prominent industry players have courses in the region.

Courses in colder climates have higher costs relative to those in more temperate climates, since owners may need to replace large stretches of greens after very cold or very dry seasons. The Mid-Atlantic region has a high golfing population.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Chemicals permitted for use on golf courses are regulated by the EPA, depending on location to ensure minimal effect on surrounding wildlife.
Underground storage tanks (USTs) used to store hazardous materials must be concrete-lined steel or double-walled, or sometimes retrofitted with detection and spill-prevention equipment.
Golf courses and country clubs are subject to federal, state and local laws preventing the disposal of waste and chemicals into the water and air.

Golf courses and country clubs must have appropriate licensing from the county or city to sell food and liquor on their property. Because of the amount of waste produced by food services, proper disposal of food waste is highly regulated as well.

Golf courses and country clubs require a significant labor force to work as servers, busboys, bartenders, caddies, custodians and childcare providers. Owners must observe adequate workplace health and safety conditions, in addition to providing employees with the local minimum wage and abiding by overtime rules established as part of the act.

Golf courses are municipal and must be accommodating to the disabled population. Private courses are not required to follow ADA guidelines unless they become open to the general public, even if only temporarily.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The industry is in the decline life cycle stage, indicating high barriers to entry.

basis_points.basis_title: Competition between many small companies and large operators
basis_points.basis_description: There is competition between many small companies and a few large operators over the same populations. The existence of small companies prevents large ones from growing their operations.
Golf players have an abundance of choice when it comes to where they will play. It ultimately comes down to the quality of services and cost of playing at a club or course.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Number of Companies Operating a Single Course
concentration_points.concentration_description: Most larger companies operate hundreds of courses, while several medium-size companies own and operate anywhere from a couple to dozens of courses. There are thousands of additional independent or public establishments that operate a single course only. Smaller operations may have difficulties in achieving economies of scale compared to companies operating many courses.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Large Companies to Consolidate as Small Establishments Face Financial Pressure
concentration_points.concentration_description: Larger companies are constantly investing in more golf courses to grow their portfolios and stature. There are opportunities for large companies to consolidate as small establishments face financial pressure. There are high costs associated with acquiring existing courses and country clubs, so companies need the finances to back up any mergers and acquisitions.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Maintenance of irrigation systems makes up the bulk of this segment; golf courses and country clubs require extensive water systems to maintain their pristine landscape.
Capital expenses also include vehicles, golf carts, lawn mowers and other maintenance machinery, along with kitchen and computer equipment.
Golf course expenses consist of various recurring purchases, including fertilizers, food, beverages, pro shop gear, golf equipment for resale and rental and other miscellaneous materials.
Most country clubs have an abundance of workers. Many jobs in the industry, like caddies, servers, and bartenders, are physically demanding.
There is also a lot of physical labor that is required to operate a golf course; golf courses require hand hands-on maintenance to provide aesthetically pleasing greens.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Running a golf course efficiently is very labor intensive, as operators need to employ servers and caddies, as well as workers to maintain the greens.

The industry is experiencing a low level of both the rate of new patents and the concentration of patents in the industry. This creates an environment where the threat of new technologies driving disruption is low.

Major market segments for industry operators are relatively diversified. The spread of market segments suggests that there are limited entry points other than those already served my incumbent operators.

volatility_points.volatility_description: For many country clubs, especially the more prestigious ones, membership is extremely exclusive and in high demand. Many clubs have substantial waiting lists to become a member, meaning the pool of potential members is constantly refilling.
Some clubs will charge a start-up fee in addition to annual membership fees, which discourages people from letting their memberships lapse.

Membership rates rarely fluctuate, but in a poor economic climate there will inevitably be a decline in new membership and membership renewal. New membership typically decreases in line with declines in the unemployment rate, per capita disposable income or consumer spending levels in general.
In 2020 alone, industry revenue decreased 3.4%, the greatest decrease in revenue since 2009, primarily as a result of the poor economic conditions brought on by the COVID-19 pandemic.

FAQs.question: How well does your company market to consumers with limited leisure time?
FAQs.answer: Industry operators often struggle to appeal to consumers with limited leisure time since a round of golf is time consuming. Nevertheless, some industry operators have attempted to appeal to time-strapped consumers by offering smaller courses and ancillary services.

FAQs.question: Does seasonality affect sales for the products and services your company offers?
FAQs.answer: Seasons have a strong effect on industry demand since most consumer demand for golf is in the warm summer months. Courses that are located in states with mild climates year-round, typically are able to operate throughout the year. Courses that are more affected by winter weather will likely limit operations during the off months.

FAQs.question: If your company benefits from population density, are you located in high traffic areas to increase your exposure?
FAQs.answer: Industry operators must strike a balance when it comes to locations; operators benefit from locating near many downstream clients, though enterprises need access to enough affordable land to build a large course. Although population density is an important factor to attract customers, locating near affluent communities is also a key element for operators since high income earners are a large market segment.

FAQs.question: Are your products and services well-rounded to mitigate sudden changes in demand?
FAQs.answer: Industry operators generally struggle during periods of weak economic demand, and changes in other demand drivers, since the industry's largest customer base is wealthy consumers.

FAQs.question: Has your company explored lowering wage costs through part-time labor and automation via point-of-sale systems?
FAQs.answer: In recent years, average industry wages have increased. The industry is heavily reliant on customer service and physical labor. Therefore, to attract higher skilled employees, industry operators may have to increase wages.

FAQs.question: Have you established a strong internet presence through social media platforms to capture a larger audience?
FAQs.answer: Many industry operators are working to grow their online and social media presence since younger generations are often swayed by online content and many players are looking to appeal to younger consumers. However, some clubs have built a reputation of being exclusive and therefore do not wish to have a strong online presence. These clubs depend on a loyal customer base.

FAQs.question: Are you up-to-date with legislative and regulatory changes that may allow your company to expand into new markets?
FAQs.answer: Many of the larger industry players employ in-house compliance teams to ensure they are up-to-date with regulatory changes.

FAQs.question: Do you offer membership agreements, tickets or passes that may be subject to state or federal regulation?
FAQs.answer: Regulations regarding membership agreements and day passes vary by state, and many large industry operators employ in-house compliance teams.

FAQs.question: Is your company's profit margin in step with major competitors?
FAQs.answer: The average industry profit margin is low and significantly brought down by public courses that operate as nonprofit entities. Profit is expected to have decreased over the past five years due to reduced demand. In 2023, the average industry profit margin is expected to account for 1.1% of industry revenue.

FAQs.question: Do you develop off-season demand through alternative products and services to maintain steady cash flow during slower seasons?
FAQs.answer: During the off-season, industry operators rely on demand for ancillary services, such as meals in the dining room and personal training sessions at the fitness center.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to increase membership fees? How else have you mitigated cost increases?
FAQs.answer: Golf course and country club operators that are able to pass on cost increases are in a better position to boost profit.

FAQs.question: How do you have a high turnover rate? Does your staff undergo constant training?
FAQs.answer: Clubs in this industry need a highly competent workforce, including greenkeepers, restaurant staff and golf professionals and instructors. Having a skilled, professional staff is a key element in differentiating clubs from each other and providing value to consumers.

FAQs.question: How many industry-relevant properties do you own? Are you able to leverage economies of scale?
FAQs.answer: Companies that operate many golf courses and country clubs can reduce average administrative and maintenance costs, which can increase profit.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor household income in your area? Do you offer a variety of memberships?
FAQs.answer: Consumers often decide on large expenses, such as country club or golf course memberships, based on changes in disposable incomes and their perceived ability to maintain current income levels in the future. In 2023, consumer confidence is expected to decrease.

FAQs.question: Do you expect major changes in demand due to rising per capita disposable income? How do you appeal to consumers with less disposable income?
FAQs.answer: An increase in per capita disposable income generally translates to higher golf participation among casual golfers, raising revenue from green fees and benefiting the industry. Per capita disposable income is expected to increase in 2023.

FAQs.question: What percentage of your members earn more than $100,000 annually? How can you appeal to new clients in this demographic?
FAQs.answer: Country club memberships are often very expensive; therefore, wealthier individuals are the most likely consumers to spend a significant amount of money annually on green fees and club memberships. In 2023, the number of households earning more than $100,000 is expected to increase.
